introduction.p: Earlier we studied products of polynomials, and in particular we found expanded forms for powers of binomials such as (a+b)^2 and (a+b)^3. The amount of work involved in expanding such powers increases as the exponent gets larger. In this section we will learn how to raise a binomial to any positive integer power, without having to perform the polynomial products.

subsection.title: The Binomial Coefficient
subsection.p: Now we continue our study of powers of binomials. What should the expansion of (a+b)^6 look like? From the Iinvestigation we know that it should have 7 terms, with the exponents on a decreasing from 6 down to 0, and the exponents on b increasing from 0 up to 6.

subsection.title: Using Pascal's Triangle
subsection.p: We can now write the expanded form of any binomial power without having to perform the multiplication.

statement.p: Find the expanded form of (3r-q)^6 without performing the multiplication.

solution.p:
(a+b)^6 = a^6 + a^5b+a^4b^2+a^3b^3++a^2b^4+ab^5+b^6
Next, fill in the blanks with the binomial coefficients from Pascal's triangle.
(a+b)^6 = a^6 + 6a^5b+15a^4b^2+20a^3b^3+15a^2b^4+6ab^5+b^6
Finally, replace a by 3r and replace b by -q, then simplify to find
(3r-q)^6 \amp = (3r)^6 + 6(3r)^5(-q) + 15(3r)^4(-q)^2 + 20(3r)^3(-q)^3 \amp\qquad\qquad + 15(3r)^2(-6)^4 + 6(3r)(-q)^5 + (-q)^6 \amp = 729r^6 - 1458r^5q + 1215r^4q^2 - 540r^3q^3 + 135r^2q^2 - 18rq^5 + q^6

subsection.title: Factorial Notation
subsection.p: Finding binomial coefficients from Pascal's triangle is tedious for large values of n. It would be convenient to have a formula for calculating the coefficients directly. For this formula we need a new symbol, n! (read "n factorial"), which is defined as follows:

assemblage.title: Factorial
assemblage.p: If n is a positive integer, n! = n \cdot (n-1) \cdot (n-2) \cdot \cdots \cdot 3\cdot 2 \cdot 1

note.p: The factorial symbol applies only to the variable or number it follows; for example, 3 \cdot 4! is not equal to (3 \cdot 4)!.

note.p: You can check that the formula works for k=0 when we use 0! = 1. You should find that ~_nC_0~ = \dfrac{n!}{(n-0)!~0!} = \dfrac{n!}{n!~(1)} = 1 so the formula correctly gives us the coefficient of a^n in the expansion of (a+b)^n.

subsection.p: We now have two methods for computing the binomial coefficient ~_nC_k~ : Pascal's triangle and our formula using factorials. When n is small, especially if all the coefficients of the binomial expansion are needed, Pascal's triangle is often the easier choice. But when n is large or if only one coefficient is required, the factorial formula for ~_nC_k~ is probably quicker than Pascal's triangle.

statement.p: Find the coefficient of m^{11}n^3 in the expansion of (m+n)^{14}.

solution.p: We are simply replacing a with m and b with n in the expansion of (a+b)^{14}, so the term containing m^{11}n^3 has n=14 and k=3, and its coefficient is ~_{14}C_3~. ~_{14}C_3~ = \dfrac{14!}{(14-3)!~3!} = \dfrac{14 \cdot 13 \cdot 12 \cdot 11!}{11!~3!} = \dfrac{14 \cdot 13 \cdot 12}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 364 The coefficient of m^{11}n^3 is 364.

subsection.title: The Binomial Theorem
subsection.p:
Consider the expansion of (a+b)^6 written with the ~_nC_k~ notation for the coefficients.
(a+b)^6 = \amp ~a^6b^0 + ~_6C_1~ a^5b^1 +~_6C_2~ a^4b^2 + ~_6C_3~ a^3b^3 + ~_6C_4~ a^2b^4 + ~_6C_5~ a^1b^5 + ~_6C_6~ a^0b^6 \amp k = 0~~~~~~~~k = 1~~~~~~~~~~~k = 2~~~~~~~~~~~~ k = 3~~~~~~~~~~~~ k = 4~~~~~~~~~~~~ k = 5~~~~~~~~~~~~ k = 6
Check that each term can be written in the form {}_6C_k~ a^{6-k}b^k for k=0 to k=6. This means that we can use sigma notation to write the sum of the terms in the expansion.
(a+b)^6 = \sum_{k=0}^{6} ~_6C_k~ a^{6-k}b^k
Notice that the sigma notation indicates terms for k=0 to k=6, so there are 7 terms in the expansion, as there should be. Also note that the sum of the exponents on a and b is (6-k)+k = 6.

The equation above is a special case of the binomial theorembinomial theorem, which uses everything we have learned to write the expanded form of a power of a binomial in the most compact form possible. We can write the general form of the theorem, for positive integers n, as follows.

ol.li: Use sigma notation to write the expanded form for (x-2y)^{10}.
Find the term containing y^7, and simplify.
We apply the binomial theorem with n=10, replacing a by x and b by -2y, to get (x-2y)^{10} = ~~\displaystyle{\sum_{k=0}^{10} ~_{10}C_k~ x^{10-k}(-2y)^k}

The term containing y^7 corresponds to k=7. The k=7 term looks like ~_{10}C_7~ x^{10-7}(-2y)^7~~~~\text{or} ~~~~ ~_{10}C_7~ x^3(-2y)^7 The value of ~_{10}C_7~ is ~_{10}C_7~ = \dfrac{10!}{(10-7)!~7!} = \dfrac{10 \cdot 9 \cdot 8 \cdot 7!}{3!~7!} = \dfrac{10 \cdot 9 \cdot 8}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 120 and (-2y)^7 = -128y^7. Thus, the term we want is ~_{10}C_7~ x^3 (-2y)^7 = 120x^3(-128y^7) = -15,360x^3y^7
